fields.description:
Burndown chart is missing issues when issue is transitioned in the same second that issue was created.

*Steps to reproduce:*
 1. create issue and immediately transition it to other status (eg. by using rest API, Automation) so that transition happens in the same second that the issue was created in
 2. use issue in the sprint
 3. close sprint
 4. go to burndown chart - the issue is not in the "start sprint" row

*Actual behaviour*
 # Issue was missing from the Burndown Chart but not Sprint Report. The issue key will appear after issue was resolved and Sprint was ended.
 # Story points was not calculated in the Burndown Chart.

*Expected behaviour*
 Issue is included in the "start sprint" row

*Possible workaround*
 # Backup JIRA
 # Update the "created" field of offending changegroup and jiraissue
{code:java}
alter table jiraissue modify column created datetime(3);

alter table changegroup modify column created datetime(3);{code}
(i) The SQL query is applicable for MySQL database.
 (i) The column names are case insensitive in MySQL, but some third-party tool may store cached column names in uppercase ("CREATED"), ex. Power BI reporting tools. This will not cause any problems for Jira, but may require some schema refresh for this tools.

 # Restart JIRA
 # Reindex instance
fields.summary: burndown chart is missing issues in start sprint row

fields.description:
My team uses feature branches pushed to github to do code reviews. Sometimes the code review is denied and the developer has to resubmit work on a new branch. It seem that Jira smart commits watch all branches instead of just master, so that the #resolve smart commit tag is applied as soon as the code review branch is created, rather than when it's merged into the main corpus of code. This of course then shows an incorrect status on the Jira issue, since it's not actually resolved, just "pending" until the code is verified to actually work.

Is there any way to tell Jira to sync only one or two specific branches?
fields.summary: Seeking the ability sync only one or two specific branches

fields.description:
{panel:title=Atlassian Update - 26 Jan 2021|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#ebf2f9 | titleBGColor=#ebf2f9 | bgColor=#ffffff}
Hi everyone,

Starting from version 8.16.0, Jira will display an inline error message next to the "Epic Link" field if a user tries to use an Epic that they don't have edit permissions to.

 !Screenshot 2021-01-26 at 16.10.12.png|thumbnail! 

Regards,
Daniel Rauf
Software Engineer, Jira Data Center
{panel}

OVERVIEW

The "Epic Link" field on screens (e.g. during issue creation or editing) shows all Epics in projects for which the user has the "Browse Projects" permission. However, in order to actually create the link the user needs the "Edit Issues" permission for both the Epic and the issue being created/edited (note: not the "Link Issues" permission). If the user attempts to create/edit an issue and link to an Epic that the user does not have permission to link to (i.e. in another project with different permissions), no error or warning is given on saving the changes and the resulting Epic Link field is left blank.

STEPS TO REPRODUCE

# Create two projects PROJA and PROJB.
# Create an epic in PROJA.
# Create a user and grant them *only* the "Browse Projects" permission for PROJA, and all permissions for PROJB.
# Log in as the above user.
# Create an issue in PROJB and use the "Epic Link" field to find the epic created in PROJA.
# Having created the issue, verify that no warning/error was given to say that the user doesn't have permission to link to the selected epic, and that the Epic Link field has been left empty.

USE CASE

We have a large number of teams working on a single JIRA instance across multiple projects. For reasons I won't go into (but can if need be), it is common for work in one project to be linked to an Epic in another. We also want to allow everyone to be able to "view" what is going on across the business in all projects, but want to control who can link to Epics in specific projects. Hence, all users are granted the "Browse Projects" permission, but further permissions are granted on a project by project basis, and users are only able to link to a small fraction of the projects which they can view.

The problems this bug causes with this use case are:

# A large number of Epics (several hundred in our case) are made available to a user even though they can't link to them in reality. Some other recent changes have made finding Epics easier, but it is still frustrating to have so many irrelevant Epics in the field.
# If a mistake is made (very easy when many projects have similarly named Epics) and an unlinkable Epic is selected, the lack of warning/error means that this can go unnoticed by users, and can be much harder to rectify in hindsight.

SUGGESTED FIXES

My preferred solution would be for the Epic Link field to only show Epics which the user can link to. If there is a reason I can't foresee for wanting to have unlinkable Epics in the screen, then at least providing a warning or preferably an error when the link is attempted would also be helpful, but would in the end only serve to highlight the underlying problem with the Epics shown in the Epic Link field.
fields.summary: Epic Link field allows selection of unlinkable Epics without warning/error

fields.description:
h3. Summary

JS Exception occurs when user create a new issue from Active sprint UI. A red error dialog appears as attached.

h3. Environment

* Server
** Mac OS 
** Linux 
* Client
** Firefox 47, Chrome 51.X, Safari 9.1.1 on Mac OS X
** IE Edge on Windows 10 

h3. Steps to Reproduce

It’s easy to reproduce by clean install.

# Install JIRA Software 7.1.8.
# Install JIRA Service Desk 7.1.8 in addition to JIRA Software instance above.
# Change user’s preference language from English to Japanese or Spanish in Profile UI.
# Create Scrum software project newly, or you may use existing project.
# Create a sprint and create some issues in backlog, then drug and drop these issues into the sprint.
# Start the sprint, then you should go to scrum board as Active sprints UI.
# Create a new ticket from Active sprints UI, by clicking 'Create' button in JIRA header.
# Exception occurs as attached.
{code}
An error occurredHide…
Please try refreshing the page, or contact your administrator / Atlassian Support if the problem continues.
Details
Exception: Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read property '1' of null
Resource: http://54.178.170.32:8080/s/4b15b6e3d45724794a43ccf12e1a840f-CDN/ja_JP41e2a9/71011/b6b48b2829824b869586ac216d119363/a5d59193dcba921eb31dd32e8b5f7d21/_/download/contextbatch/js/greenhopper-rapid-non-gadget,atl.general,gh-rapid,jira.global,jira.project.sidebar,jira.general,-_super/batch.js?agile_global_admin_condition=true&hc-enabled=true&is-server-instance=true&is-system-admin=true&jag=true&jaguser=true&locale=ja-JP&nps-acknowledged=true&nps-not-opted-out=true&sd_licensed=true
Line: 9769
Column: 392
Environment
Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10_10_5) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/51.0.2704.103 Safari/537.36
{code}

*Note:*
- The same error occurs even if you install JIRA Service Desk first, and then install JIRA Software.
- This error doesn’t occur in Atlasssian Cloud environment.
- This error doesn’t occur in English.

h3. Expected Results

at 8 above, a new ticket should be created without exception.

h3. Actual Results

The exception occurs. Exception in each browser is different by browser. but occurs in same line.

* Chrome
!error-chrome.png|thumbnail! 

* Edge
!error-edge.png|thumbnail! 

h3.Workaround

Currently, there is no workaround for this problem. User needs to go other UIs to create a new issue.

fields.description:
The documentation for Jira 6 and Jira 7 are inconsistent
Jira 6 : https://confluence.atlassian.com/jira064/connecting-jira-to-postgresql-720411771.html
Jira 7.0 : https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/AdminJIRAServer070/Connecting+JIRA+applications+to+PostgreSQL
Jira 7.1 : https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/AdminJIRAServer071/Connecting+JIRA+applications+to+PostgreSQL

The following tag are missing and should be added to the dbconfig.xml sample file configuration
{code:java}
<pool-test-on-borrow>false</pool-test-on-borrow>
{code}
In both of the Jira 7.0 and 7.1 documentation above, the tag mentioned above should be set to false as mentioned in the Jira 6 documentation so that the health check passes and avoid this error to being seen during the Health Check:
 !pool-borrow.png|thumbnail! 
For more information please refer to : https://confluence.atlassian.com/jirakb/health-check-database-configuration-792636748.html
fields.summary: Inconsistent documentation for Connecting JIRA applications to PostgreSQL

fields.description:
h3. Summary

Velocity chart includes an estimation of Story that is completed outside the Sprint.

h3. Steps to Reproduce

# Have a project and a board with Story Point as estimation
# Create 2 Sprints (Sprint 1 and 2), a few issues, estimate each of them and assign to the Sprint 1
# Start Sprint 1
# Complete an issue (i.e ABC-1) by dragging to the right most column (i.e move to Closed)
# Reopen it by moving it to the left most column
# Complete Sprint 1 and move the incomplete issues (ABC-1) to Sprint 2
# Go to ABC-1 and move to _Closed_ status
# Create some issues, estimate them and assign to Sprint 2
# Start Sprint 2 and complete it.

h3. Current Result

- Velocity Chart includes the estimation of ABC-1 in *Commitment* column while Burndown Chart doesn't include it.


h3. Expected Result

- Velocity Chart doesn't include the estimation of ABC-1 in *Commitment* column just like Burndown Chart as the issue is complete outside the Sprint.
fields.summary: Velocity chart includes an estimation of a Story that is completed outside the Sprint

fields.description:
I want to have a board that displays issues based on two criterias: 
ALL issuetypes with value "TheComponent" in field "component" AND issuetype Epic with value "AnotherComponent" in field "component" 

Example: 
project in ("TheProject") AND component = "TheComponent"OR project in ("TheProject") AND issuetype = Epic AND component = "AnotherComponent" ORDER BY Rank ASC

When using this filter the correct issues are displayed in the backlog, but the statusmapping to columns (board configuration) does not show the statuses I expect - it seems only the statuses for Epic is available.
I would expect the statuses for the other issuetypes would also be available, since the filter displays the other issuestypes and not only Epics. 

The workaround is to add a query for all issuestypes to the first part of the query, then all statuses are visible in the mapping to columns. 
However, it seems to be a disparity between how the filter works and which statuses that are available in the status - column mapping. 


(Seems I cannot add attachments, but what I mean with status - column mapping is Board -> Configure -> Columns) The epic has less statuses than the other issuetypes, and without the workaround only the epic statuses are available for mapping to columns, not the statuses from the other issue types, even though they are visible on the board.)
fields.summary: Unexpected behaviour for boardfilters when issuetype is part of a query

h3. Summary

While the 'Create' button at the top of the page might be dependent on browser session rather than current page being displayed, the "Create Epic" button of an Agile board should default to the board's Project.  The "Create Version" button behaves in the expected way, filling in the Project field correctly based on the Board being viewed, but not the "Create Epic" one.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Visit an agile board.
# In another tab/window, visit another project or an issue in another project.
# Return to the agile board window, and click "Create Epic" (under "Epics").

h3. Expected Results
"Project" will be populated with the current board's Project.

h3. Actual Results
"Project" is populated with the Project you visited in the other tab/window.

h3. Notes
Similar to [JRA-14191 - "Create new issue" project wrong when working with multiple projects simultaneously|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRA-14191]

Check which project has been filled in and correct it if needed before completing the Epic creation process.

fields.description:
h3. Summary

* Generating JIRA stories from a Confluence Product Requirement table will truncate the description in the JIRA issue that is created if description is > 254 characters.

h3. Environment
* JIRA Cloud - version 1000.110.0

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a new page in Confluence using Product Requirements blueprint
# List 2 or more requirements in the table
# In User Story column, add more than 254 characters of text for one requirement
# Highlight the Title of one of the requirements in the table
# Click on *Create JIRA Issue* icon
# Click on *Create multiple issues from table*
# Select a JIRA project for the issue
# Select *User Story* from the Description drop down
# Click Create
# Open the newly created issue that had a long User Story

h3. Expected Results

* Full content of User Story column from Product Requirement table is copied over to Description in JIRA issue

h3. Actual Results

* Up to 245 characters are copied over followed by ellipses (...)
 
h3.Workaround

* Copy full User Story content from Confluence and paste in to description for JIRA issue
fields.summary: Generating Stories from Product Requirements Shortens Long Description

fields.description:
As of today, Jira supports linking of commits (I use Mercurial, but I guess it works for Git as well) to Jira issues via the commit message. 
We use feature branches and our custom is to use the Jira issue as the branch name. e.g., my branch name could be "PRJ-331" where I will work on issue PRJ-331. Today, if I want the commits in the branch to be associated with the issue, I need to explicitly add the issue key to each and every commit message in the branch. What I'm requesting is that if the branch name includes an issue key, have all the commits in it linked to the issue automatically.

Thanks.
fields.summary: Link commits in a feature branch to a Jira issue

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
The plugin provides a ReviewsCompleteCondition, which creates a questionable dependency between Jira and Fisheye/Crucible. The condition is called when displaying the issue page, and any problems on the Fisheye side can lead to serious delays in Jira. It also appears that the condition is called for actions when it is not needed (e.g. commenting or inline editing) though we are not 100% certain about this.

A good solution is to also provide the check in the form of a *transition Validator*, so that fisheye is called only when the transition is actually executed. A problem in fisheye at least only causes a localized problem in Jira. If the transition cannot be executed due to failure of the check, a message should appear alerting the user to the problem and providing links to the offending reviews.
fields.summary: Jira Fisheye/Crucible plugin: The plugin should provide a ReviewsComplete check as a transition validator.

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
A customer has reported that the internal JIRA documentation is incomplete when adding a fecru project to JIRA. 

{quote}
If you simply establish an application link between a JIRA project and a FishEye repository: then the source view in JIRA will only show the commits/changes that include the JIRA issue number in the commit log.

If however, you set a path in the JIRA setings: then the source view in JIRA will show all commits, regardless of what the commit log contains.

This difference in behaviour is not documented and is actually rather annoying if you must use a repository path in the JIRA project settings (like for example, when using a common repository for several projects)
{quote}

Perhaps this needs looking at as the finer details of the doco may not cover this.
fields.summary: Mapping FishEye/Crucible project to JIRA project not behaving as per documentation

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
When there's a large number of files changed in one SVN revision, the list under the corresponding ticket in JIRA (under the "source" tab) gets truncated. This sometimes leads to human errors when reviewing or porting code or investigating root causes of some issues. It makes it impossible to use "Search" safely on the JIRA page to check whether a specific file or file type has been changed, requiring the users to traverse to the fisheye repository, sometimes multiple times per single ticket.
!Screen Shot 2015-08-24 at 17.35.39.png|thumbnail!

h3. Suggested Solution
Provide the opportunity for JIRA admins to configure the number of files showed for every revision showed in the Development Panel.

This could be configured in FishEye/Crucible Configuration panel in JIRA.
!Screen Shot 2015-08-24 at 17.37.03.png|thumbnail!
fields.summary: As a JIRA admin I want to configure how many files are showed in Development Panel commit Files list

Currently, JIRA source tab user interface do not handle the exception well enough. Let takes a scenario where the integration between FishEye and JIRA is using trusted application, two user had the right to access the issue but one of the user does not actually have the rights to access the repository in FishEye. When user does not has the right to access the FishEye repository it will have the following exception in the UI:

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
Currently, instead of the activity stream gadget, there is no other way to search issues that have changesets or reviews associated with it.

Would be beneficial to have the ability of insert custom fields and use them to build a JQL search, as this example:

# Custom Field "Last Revision" = 123456
# Custom Field "Revision Branch" = 'Trunk'
# Custom Field "Reviewed in Crucibe" = Y/N
# Custom Field "Review Status" = crucible latest review status or N/A
fields.summary: Add ability of search issues that have changesets or reviews associated

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
Since the introduction of Application Links, administrator need to go to each Project in order to map FishEye's repository with the JIRA's Project. 

This caused a lot of time spent on mapping the repositories with the projects(eg:4 hours) especially for medium to large instance as the mapping might involving hundreds of projects and repositories.
fields.summary: Allow Project and Repository Mapping To Be Done In FishEye Configuration Screen

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
The JIRA Issue Source Tab shows the latests changesets from the [oldest to the most recent|^screenshot1.png] (top to bottom).

It would be nice to have a way to change the order on how the changesets are displayed in the source tab (e.g. from most recent to oldest).
fields.summary: Change Changesets Order in JIRA Issue Source Tab

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
It would be great if you could specify a string in an issue that would get used to match the issue to a Fisheye changeset. 

Previously we were using FogBugz, so in order to get the link between a FogBugz issue and a changeset, our commit messages have (for example) 'Case 123' in them. We've now migrated our issues to JIRA, but this means that the new JIRA ID (for example XYZ-123) no longer matches and so we don't get the link in Fisheye.

My initial plan of attack was to edit the history in our source control so that the old FogBugz issue was replaced by the JIRA issue. However, we use Mercurial and changing history is quite complex.

It would be great if each issue had a 'Fisheye Issue ID' field which defaulted to the JIRA ID but could be changed. That way we could go through the imported issues and change this value to the old FogBugz issue ID and get the Source tab integration working as normal. You could even set this value instead of/as well as the External Issue ID when importing from other issue tracking systems.
fields.summary: Allow links to Fisheye changesets based on a custom property

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
We have cases where many Jira projects use a large group of repos. This use case causes us huge effort in creating the links between Jira and Fisheye. Assume there are 10 Jira projects and 50 repos. The fisheye plugin now requires us to create 500 applinks by hand:(. We are now facing a support case that may require us to recreate several thousand applinks: https://support.atlassian.com/browse/FSH-9879.

What can be done?

I can think of a few things:

* Fisheye has projects. If there is one Fisheye project that already includes the 50 repos (this is in fact the case for us), then it would suffice to link the 10 Jira projects with the 1 Fisheye project. This would reduce the number of manually created links to 50, a 10x saving in effort. Our experience, however, is that the Jira project must be linked *both* to the Fisheye project *and* the repos.

* I have found out that the fisheye plugin in jira-4.2 and below allowed you to link a repo with many projects in one action (see https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/uYCQDg and comment of 10.9 below), but this is no longer possible. This functionality would reduce our 500 actions to 50!

* Why are project-specific repo applinks needed at all? We assume this is because it would take too long to search all repos in Fisheye for a given issue, but surely this is a problem that can be solved by an appropriate index in Fisheye, something Atlassian is very good at:).

* Failing all this, how about an API call that creates the applinks so at least we can script this?
fields.summary: Reduce effort in creating jira-fisheye applinks.

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
FishEye 2.7 and FishEye Plugin 3.4.5 let you set up smart commits (finally yeah !!)

As per http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/FISHEYE/Using+Smart+Commits

you can add keyword in your commit message and the designed jira issue will be updated accordingly.

It would be nice to have the possibility to add in the comment the commit number where the change occurred.
So for SVN we would have something like:
In svn:XXXX ...
or:
In git:[hash] ....

etc.
fields.summary: Add ability to include in comment revision number where change got committed

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
Most of our user community likes the new Development Panel in JIRA 6.2+.  However, some of our projects prefer the previous tabbed display.  It allowed for more information to be displayed directly on the JIRA detail screen (ie Crucible review details, Objectives etc).

We would like to see an option added to the Project Administration -> Development tools config screen that would allow project admins to select whether to use the Source, Build and Review (esp this one) tabs, or use the Development Panel instead.
fields.summary: Make Development Panel vs detail tabs configurable on a per project basis

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
If you view the "source" tab of an issue, and then click "Create crucible review", a new crucible review will be created.  The review will be automatically populated with all the files found in the source tab.  

Unfortunately, if any of those files is large, then when the review is viewed, Crucible will quickly run out of heap and max out the cpu cores trying to doing garbage collection.  Only a restart of the Crucible will return things to normal.  

I ran into this issue when one of the files in a review was 28M.  I iterated with Atlassian support for a while (CRC-2795) and we both agreed that the underlying problem is actually with Crucible and the fact that it goes bonkers when there is a large file involved.  However, this is apparently a known issue with Crucible, and there doesn't seem to be a way to fix it at the present time.  Therefore, this enhancement request for the fisheye pluging:  That when a person clicks on the "Create crucible review", there should be an intermediate page that shows the size of the files that will be included in the review, and allows one to remove large files from the review.
fields.summary: Create crucible review link should allow for removing large files from a review before the review is created.

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
When a repository is removed, or when there has been any change in FishEye repositories, JIRA does not update the FishEye repository list cache automatically. This needs to be done manually, as follows in FishEye configuration administration screen:

!refresh repository list cache.PNG!

This information is not mentioned anywhere in our documentation. I suggest that we mention it here (especially that many support tickets are about this issue and including this information can save our time and our customers' time):
https://studio.plugins.atlassian.com/wiki/display/FISH/Troubleshooting+FishEye+for+JIRA

or here:
http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA043/Integrating+JIRA+with+FishEye

or even in both places.

Thanks,
Ali
Atlassian Support
fields.summary: Information worth mentioning in Troubleshooting JIRA FishEye Plugin documentation

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
h3. Current behaviour:
If you have an application link with Fisheye you can associate a Repository Path with a project, the current behaviour of this association is described [here|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Integrating+JIRA+with+FishEye#IntegratingJIRAwithFishEye-Notes]:
{quote}
*Associating a JIRA Project with a Repository Path —* Once an application link has been established between JIRA and a FishEye site, you can associate a Repository Path on that FishEye site with a JIRA project, via the *'Select Path'* link of the 'Repository Path' option in the 'Settings' section of JIRA's [Project Configuration area|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Defining+a+Project#DefiningaProject-configure]. Specifying a Repository Path changes the behaviour of the 'Source' tab on a JIRA issue:
* If no Repository Path is specified, the 'Source' tab on a JIRA issue will only show the commits/changes which include that JIRA issue number in the commit log.
* If a Repository Path is specified, the 'Source' tab on a JIRA issue will show all commits/changes made in this repository path.
{quote}

h3. Proposed Results:
It'd be good to have the option to restrict per groups the information of the 'Source' tab to display *only* the commits/changes into a specific Repository Path. E.g.: Content of Repository Path _/projects/jira/_ only be accessible per members of group _Test_.
fields.summary: Add ability to restrict a Repository Path per groups

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
In JIRA 3.13.x, it was possible to see the Crucible review ID in the JIRA issue's "FishEye" tab (nowadays called "Source" tab).
However, this information was removed in newer versions of JIRA, such as in JIRA 4.3.x, and it's nowadays only displayed in the "Reviews" tab.

This, however, does not allow users to see if a specific changeset has been reviewed or not, and this is a pitfall to create multiple reviews for the same changeset.
fields.summary: Display the Crucible review ID in the Source tab

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
When a user attempts to remove a configured repository path from *"Project Administration > Settings"*, the following behavior is observed:
# User clicks on the *Delete* button, like so: [^DeletePath1.jpg]
# In the next page, the confirmation dialog appears, and the user clicks on *Delete*, like so: [^DeletePath2.jpg]
# After clicking the button, nothing happens and the following text appears on the page ([^DeletePath3.jpg]): 
{noformat}
Are you sure you want to remove the repository path mapping null from project null?
{noformat}
# Clicking on the *Delete* button does nothing, and the page stays at the message as per above. Going back to the Project Administration page, the repository path is still there and not deleted. 


*STEPS TO REPRODUCE*
# Install JIRA 6.0.3
# Install FishEye 3.0.1. Add a Subversion, Perforce or Git repository.
# Configure application link from JIRA to FishEye
# Create a new project, and configure a Repository Path to one of the repositories created in step 2.
# Try to delete the repository path. 


*OTHER INFORMATION*
# Tested on Subversion/Perforce/Git repositories.
# Tested on Trusted/Basic authentication for the app link.
# There are no errors in the *atlassian-jira.log* files.
fields.summary: Cannot remove FishEye Repository Path in project administration page

fields.description:
In a Stash and JIRA setup:
# create a ticket in a project FOO, say *FOO-1*
# commit and push a change referring to this ticket in its commit message
# move the ticket to a different project BAR (assume that we get *BAR-2*)
# navigate to the _Source_ tab for *BAR-2*

The change referring to *FOO-1* is not visible. Since JIRA internally maintains information to redirect you from *FOO-1* to *BAR-2* and since the indexing that populates data in the _Source_ tab in JIRA and the _Issues_ column in Stash, it would likely be possible to use the information linking *FOO-1* to *BAR-2* to populate the _Source_ tab. Without this, moving a ticket across projects irrevocably severs the link between a reported issue and changes made to resolve it.
fields.summary: The Source tab does not track changesets in Stash when you moving a ticket to another project

I created a dashboard manually and added JIRA Fisheye gadgets, set up the same Fisheye server and the same repository, and the information about the repo changes is shown perfectly, so the Fisheye's Remote API works fine and JIRA is able to connect with it.

Does anybody know which is the problem with the plugin?

fields.description:
Raised as [FISH-536|https://studio.plugins.atlassian.com/browse/FISH-536] in the plugin's bug tracker.

Steps to reproduce:
# View an issue with changesets/reviews against it
# Click on the "All" tab
# Now click on the sort arrow on the top right of the tab. The changesets & reviews will be loaded using an extra AJAX request and will sort at the top/bottom, depending on the sort order. (!)
# Alternatively, after clicking on the "All" tab navigate to another page and then come back to the issue. The changesets & reviews will be loaded using an extra AJAX request and will sort at the top/bottom, depending on the sort order. (!)

This happens because the plugin is checking the {{page}} query param in order to determine whether to AJAX-load, but in the above cases the parameter is not set even though we are loading the All tab.
fields.summary: FishEye plugin: changesets and reviews loaded out of order in the "All" tab

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
I am using the "no unreviewed changesets" and "no Open Crucible reviews" transition conditions to prevent tickets from being closed if commits have not been reviewed in Crucible. This works really well *until* there is a merge commit that has a commit message containing the JIRA issue id. This commit will show up on the issue page because the merge commit message contains the JIRA issue id. This is expected, however, this merge commit will block the ticket from being closed because the "no unreviewed changesets" wants it to be reviewed but Crucible does not support reviewing merge commits (see FE-4004). 

So, there is a chicken before the egg type problem.... "no unreviewed changesets" wants the commit to be reviewed but this isn't possible because there is no way to review it.

At least, this is what I think is happening. 

h3. To Reproduce

Reproduce steps are a little complicated because it requires a lot of configuration, but it will look something like:

# Setup Fisheye and JIRA
# Configure a JIRA workflow transaction to require "no unreviewed changesets"
It will look something like
!Transitions.png|thumbnail!
# Commit some code to an JIRA issue. Include at least one merge commit.
#* Make sure there is a merge commit message that contains the JIRA issue id.
# Review the non-merge commit. See commit list screenshot... the non-merge commit has a closed code review, but the non-merge commit does not
!Commits.png|thumbnail!
# Try to transition the issue...

Expected Behavior: Can successfully transition issue
Actual Behavior: The transition button does not appear. Presumably because the merge commit has not been reviewed.

This is becoming a problem for us when we create feature branches in Stash, and then try to use Crucible to review the changes. All Stash created branches have the JIRA issue id contained in the branch name by default, which is interfering with the  "no unreviewed changesets"  condition.

There are 2 workarounds:

# Make sure branch names don't contain JIRA issue ids. This is sub-optimal because it breaks the new JIRA 6.2 stash branch list support
# Or, disable the "no unreviewed changesets" condition. (at the risk of missing commits that need to be reviewed)
fields.summary: the "no unreviewed changesets" condition blocks transition when there is a unreviewable merge commit that contains JIRA issue id

fields.description:
Error occurs (see fisheye.jpg), when you connect JIRA and FishEye and click a link of the filename in source tab of JIRA issue detail page. The error occurs only when the file was added (not updated). See jira.jpg.

I think it is because JIRA does not escape + (plus) character. The error does not occur if I replace the character with %2B.

Here is how I reproduced:
# Install JIRA 6.3.7 and FishEye 3.5.4
# Create an Application Link between them
# Create a Development Project and an Issue on JIRA
# Add a new file which includes + (plus) character to the repository which FishEye browses with JIRA's issue key on the commit message
# Click the filename in the source tab of JIRA's issue detail page (see jira.jpg)
# The error occurs (see fisheye.jpg)
fields.summary: JIRA does not escape + (plus) character in URL to FishEye

fields.description:
h3. Summary
Whenever a workflow has a condition based on an application link (e.g. Code Committed Condition, No Open Reviews Condition, Unreviewed Code Condition), the condition will be bypassed if the user is not currently authenticated to the other application

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Add a condition to verify another application to a transition
# Make sure the user attempting the workflow transition is not connected to the other application

h3. Expected Results
Transition is not available as it cannot confirm the condition passes

h3. Actual Results
Transition is available and transitions without problems.
The following is logged
{code}
2015-07-08 15:34:15,819 http-bio-8080-exec-13 ERROR petry 934x4530x1 4becn9 192.168.10.136 /browse/TC-1 [domain.workflow.condition.ReviewsCompleteCondition] Error retrieving reviews for ReviewsCompleteCondition (TC-1). Enable logging for the FishEye plugin for more detail.
{code}
fields.summary: Fisheye Plugin Workflow Conditions based on applink bypassed when user is not authenticated to other application

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
Under the Fisheye Configuration in Jira I have an entry under "Project Repository Path Mapping" that refers to a project that no longer exists. How this happened is a mystery.  In any case, I want to delete it but cannot.  Attempting that results in:

{noformat}

*Workaround*

Log into JIRA with an account that has jira-administrator privileges
Go to Administration
Under Global Settings, go to FishEye Configuration
On the bottom of the page, go to Edit Primary Configuration
Under Display Options, set Disable for unmapped JIRA Projects: ON
Click Update, then again on the next page.
After setting Disable for unmapped JIRA Projects: back to OFF, the project disappeared from the Repository Mappings.

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
From support case:

When adding a Jira condition "must have code committed against the issue". As soon as I add the condition to even one of the transitions from a step, ALL transitions for the workflow disappear. 

Transitions disappear both from web UI as well as from SOAP (connectors also report no available transitions)
fields.summary: Adding a "must have code committed against the issue" condition to a workflow setp transition causes all workflow actions to disappear

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
When a linked Atlassian product expires and an active application link remains, JIRA performance is degraded severely.

In our example today, the evaluation license for Crucible expired. After this expired, JIRA was very slow to respond, and resource utilization on the database was greatly increased. Load times for issues went from < 1 second to 15-20 seconds average.

Immediately after applying a new evaluation license for Crucible, performance went back to normal, and load times / resource utilization dropped.

Update: This only affected JIRA users that had access to Crucible. When non-crucible users viewed a page, load times and resource utilization was normal. I am assuming this is because of the source and review tabs in JIRA.

Linked Applications:
JIRA v5.2.10#853-sha1:c0ba268
FECRU 2.10.4 Build:20130403093648 2013-04-03
Confluence 5.1.1
fields.summary: Expired license in linked application causes poor performance

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
*Steps to Reproduce*:
# Integrate JIRA with Fisheye
# Create a Test Project with several issues in JIRA
# Connect Fisheye with a Repositories.
# Do a commit which mention some of the Test Project Issue Keys.
# Navigate to the Test Project Overview Page.
# Access the Source page and click on the statistic Tab.

*Expected Result:*
The commit statistic information about the project linked to will appear.

*Actual Result:*
Nothing is shown except a broken image icon and 404 Notfound error when accessing it with the browser Developer Tools open.

!statistictab.PNG|thumbnail!
fields.summary: JIRA Project Source page Statistic Tab showing Broken Image and 404 Not Found error.

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
How to reproduce:
1. Open JIRA ticket and got to the Source tab
2. The SVN content committed to that ticket is shown.
3. Click on any source code file committed to that ticket.
4. The FishEye opens the source file.
5. Go back to the ticket and RELOAD the page.
6. The Source tab is empty: "No related source found."

Expected behavior: the Source tab always shows related content.
fields.summary: Source tab does not show content

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
Currently if an instance has FishEye disabled (all new AOD instances) the JIRA FishEye plugin is automatically disabled when JIRA is restarted (almost weekly with upgrades). 

This causes problems for users connecting behind-the-firewall FishEye to their JIRA OnDemand as they need to re-enable the plugin each week.

We also need to entirely remove the "Atlassian JIRA - OnDemand - FishEye Plugin" as it hides the Source and Reviews tabs if FishEye is not active on the OnDemand instance.
fields.summary: JIRA FishEye plugin in OnDemand should not be disabled on restart even if FishEye isn't active

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
h3. Actual Results:

Looking in the _All_ tab of an issue, the order of commits is not correct.

h3. Steps to Reproduce:

# Open an issue with commits and click on the _All_ tab;
# Notice that the order is correct;
# Now click on the _Source tab. The order will be correct;
# Clicking again in the _All_ tab now displays the right order.

!1.png|thumbnail!

!2.png|thumbnail!

!3.png|thumbnail!

h3. Expected Results:

All tabs will show the same -- correct -- order.

h3. Notes:

The order is also correct if you click to order it ascending or descending.

h3. Workaround:

Click on the _Source_ tab first.
fields.summary: Commits order is not correct in JIRA Issue View

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
*Steps to reproduce*
# Create an application link between JIRA and FishEye, link a project/repo to a JIRA project so that commits will show up on the source tab
# Create a new branch in a git repo that has a branch name with forward slash added like: *some/thing*
# Check for the branch name showing up, click on the link and notice it will fail, however the same branch name clicked in FishEye works

*Diagnosis*
When the branch link is rendered in JIRA, it will not escape forward slashes in branch names, so a link will look like:
https://localhost/fisheye/changelog/~br=some/thing/git
instead of:
https://localhost/fisheye/changelog/~br=some%402fthing/git
fields.summary: Forward slashes in branch name in FishEye break links in JIRA

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
Add a "Synchronise All" button to the FishEye plugin to re-synch the FE config.

This was part of the 4.3 plugin design, but got missed.
It would have helped us recover from CRUC-5654.

(Luis) The refresh button needs to redo the upgrade, in case something went wrong with the upgrade.
fields.summary: Need a way to force a re-synch on the FE config.

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
I have successfully added Application Links to both Jira and Fisheye to manage communication between them.
I was also able to include Fisheye Gadgets to the Jira dashboard, however, when an anonymous, not signed in user loads the dashboard, the Fisheye Gadgets are left empty. Using Firebug, I tracked the requests outgoing from the gadget. For example, the FisheyeChart gadget sends an XmlHttpRequest to the fisheye server, using the url:
http://{fisheye_domain}/rest/fegadgets/1.0/fisheyechart/generate
Inspecting the response, I see that it says that authorization is required. The status code is 401.
fields.summary: Fisheye gadgets in Jira are empty for anonymous users

fields.description:
Attempting to add a repository path in JIRA throws the following exceptions:
{noformat}
Cause
Referer URL: http://localhost:8070/jira/secure/admin/AssociateProjectRepPath!default.jspa?projectId=10101&fromScreen=prj
java.lang.NullPointerException
java.lang.NullPointerException
	at com.atlassian.jirafisheyeplugin.config.fisheye.RepositoryPathStoreImpl.getProjectId(RepositoryPathStoreImpl.java:63)
	at com.atlassian.jirafisheyeplugin.config.fisheye.RepositoryPathStoreImpl.access$400(RepositoryPathStoreImpl.java:32)
	at com.atlassian.jirafisheyeplugin.config.fisheye.RepositoryPathStoreImpl$3.with(RepositoryPathStoreImpl.java:131)
	at com.atlassian.jirafisheyeplugin.config.fisheye.RepositoryPathStoreImpl.forEachApplicationLink(RepositoryPathStoreImpl.java:144)
	at com.atlassian.jirafisheyeplugin.config.fisheye.RepositoryPathStoreImpl.reloadRepositoryPaths(RepositoryPathStoreImpl.java:118)
	at com.atlassian.jirafisheyeplugin.web.admin.AssociateProjectRepositoryPath.doExecute(AssociateProjectRepositoryPath.java:152)
	at webwork.action.ActionSupport.execute(ActionSupport.java:165)
{noformat}

Attempting to refresh the Fisheye Global configuration also throw this error:
{noformat}
2015-01-20 18:45:21,568 http-bio-8070-exec-8 ERROR admin 1125x798x1 an41kg 127.0.0.1 /secure/admin/ViewFishEyeConfig.jspa [jira.web.dispatcher.JiraWebworkActionDispatcher] Exception thrown from action 'ViewFishEyeConfig', returning 404 
org.springframework.beans.factory.BeanCreationException: Error creating bean with name 'com.atlassian.jirafisheyeplugin.web.admin.ViewFishEyeConfiguration': Instantiation of bean failed; nested exception is org.springframework.beans.BeanInstantiationException: Could not instantiate bean class [com.atlassian.jirafisheyeplugin.web.admin.ViewFishEyeConfiguration]: Constructor threw exception; nested exception is java.lang.NullPointerException
	at org.springframework.beans.factory.support.ConstructorResolver.autowireConstructor(ConstructorResolver.java:254)
	at org.springframework.beans.factory.support.AbstractAutowireCapableBeanFactory.autowireConstructor(AbstractAutowireCapableBeanFactory.java:925)
	at org.springframework.beans.factory.support.AbstractAutowireCapableBeanFactory.createBeanInstance(AbstractAutowireCapableBeanFactory.java:835)
	at org.springframework.beans.factory.support.AbstractAutowireCapableBeanFactory.doCreateBean(AbstractAutowireCapableBeanFactory.java:440)
	at org.springframework.beans.factory.support.AbstractAutowireCapableBeanFactory$1.run(AbstractAutowireCapableBeanFactory.java:409)
...
Caused by: java.lang.NullPointerException
	at com.atlassian.jirafisheyeplugin.config.fisheye.RepositoryPathStoreImpl.access$400(RepositoryPathStoreImpl.java:32)
	at com.atlassian.jirafisheyeplugin.config.fisheye.RepositoryPathStoreImpl$3.with(RepositoryPathStoreImpl.java:131)
	at com.atlassian.jirafisheyeplugin.config.fisheye.RepositoryPathStoreImpl.forEachApplicationLink(RepositoryPathStoreImpl.java:144)
	at com.atlassian.jirafisheyeplugin.config.fisheye.RepositoryPathStoreImpl.reloadRepositoryPaths(RepositoryPathStoreImpl.java:118)
	at com.atlassian.jirafisheyeplugin.config.fisheye.RepositoryPathStoreImpl.refresh(RepositoryPathStoreImpl.java:149)
	at com.atlassian.jirafisheyeplugin.config.RefreshManagerImpl.refreshRefreshables(RefreshManagerImpl.java:162)
	at com.atlassian.jirafisheyeplugin.config.RefreshManagerImpl.refreshAll(RefreshManagerImpl.java:80)
{noformat}

*Steps to reproduce:*
# Create a project.
# Associate this project with a *Repository Path* by going to the project's Administration page, scroll down to the Repository Paths section and add one there.
# Delete this project after that.
# Create a second project, but *ensure that the project key is different* from the deleted project earlier.
# Try to add a Repository Path to this project. It will fail with the 500-page error.


*Root Cause:*
# The NPE is caused by the fact that JIRA does not *update* the list of projects with repository paths in the database. 
# Running the following SQL:
{noformat}
SELECT * FROM propertyentry LEFT JOIN propertystring ON propertyentry.ID = propertystring.ID WHERE PROPERTY_KEY LIKE '%fisheye.projects.with.repository.paths%';
{noformat}
# This will populate a list of JIRA project keys that have repository paths configured.
# You will notice that this list still contains project keys of previously deleted JIRA projects. 
# The NPE occurs when the Fisheye plugin tries to retrieve the ID of a non-existent JIRA project key. 

*Workaround Steps*:
# Update the *propertystring* table row (the fisheye.projects.with.repository.paths property entry) to remove the project keys that do not exist in JIRA or has been deleted. 
# *Restart* JIRA for the database changes to take effect.
(!) ALWAYS have a database backup handy before attempting to modify production data, or test it in a staging instance first. (!)

*Tested Versions:*
# Fisheye 3.5.1 with JIRA 6.3.9
# Fisheye 3.6.2 with JIRA 6.3.9
# Fisheye 3.6.2 with JIRA 6.3.12
# Fisheye 3.7 with JIRA 6.3.14
fields.summary: NPE when adding a repository path due to previously deleted JIRA projects

Since the user was not an administrator, should I have even been taken to this page?

We have created some projects in Fisheye that not all users can read. When we commit messages on their issues, they see this error:

This list of changesets may be incomplete, as errors occurred retrieving changesets from the following repositories: • Repository Ops on http://fisheye.corp.pinger.com/ failed: Error in remote call to 'fisheye' (http://fisheye/) [AbstractRestCommand{path='/rest-service-fe/changeset-v1/listChangesets/', params={expand=changesets[-21:-1].revisions[0:29], comment=TAG-1211, p4JobFixed=TAG-1211, rep=Tag}, methodType=GET}] : Received status code 403 (Forbidden)

While it is good that they can't see these commits, it is a fairly thing for the user to see. Please revise so that the user either sees a friendly message saying they don't have access, or better yet don't show this at all.

fields.description:
h3. Summary:
With the Activity Stream Global Filter to Filter out the Enabled Stream, it would not show anything besides JIRA stream when adding a Global Filter with Username of a User that exist on both instances.

h3. Steps to Reproduce:
# Integrate JIRA with Fisheye.
# Connect a Repo to Fisheye.
# Do a Commit that mention a JIRA ticket.
# Map the Author to Fisheye User that have the same username in JIRA.
# Check if the commit is showing on the Activity Stream.
# If it does, enable the stream only from Fisheye and add a Global Filter of that specific username  of the committer.
# Refresh.

h3. Expected Result:
- The commit under that user will be the only activity shown on the Activity Stream.

h3. Actual Result:
- It will give "No activity was found"

h3. Note.
- It looks like there is some issue with the request that the Gadget throws as removing some element could retrieve the information. This is the result of a quick REST API test with the GET request.
- Original Request:
{code}http://localhost:8717/jira_717/activity?maxResults=10&streams=user+IS+julian&providers=source%409bb058fc-926b-3824-8322-34e2f9f6e93f&os_authType=basic{code}
- Modified Request that should be able to list the right activity:
{code}http://localhost:8717/jira_717/plugins/servlet/streams?maxResults=10&streams=user+IS+julian&%409bb058fc-926b-3824-8322-34e2f9f6e93f&_=1465828527612{code}
fields.summary: Activity Stream Global Filter by Username did not work for Fisheye

        at java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:744)
{code}

Notes:
* The detail module seems only break when the "Move" Operation involved. Otherwise, it behaves correctly.
fields.summary: JIRA details module break when issue with perforce job move to another project

fields.description:
h4. Actual behavior:

Trying to change the *Revision Cache Size* to a different value does not work. The value always reverts to 5000.

h4. Steps to reproduce:

# Navigate to: {{BASE.URL/secure/admin/EditFishEyeConfig!default.jspa}}
# Edit the *Revision Cache Size* and set to a value different than 5000
# Save the settings

h4. Expected behavior:

The chosen value is not saved.

h4. Workaround:

No workarounds available.
fields.summary: Application Links not updating Fisheye Revision Cache Size

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
h3.Problem

In Fisheye, a commit can be related to a directory, then no new files exist. In this case the revision is not possible

In this situation, when merging commits that result in 0 files is not possible to execute the "Resolve Issue" transition, when it requeries "no open Crucible reviews" and "no unreviewed changesets". 

Example:
* X working on ABC-1, merging ABC-2 branch in.
{quote}
    X submitted changeset 79c72334d61ce2063b87f7cdda1850cd02215289 to ABC-1 in ABC (0 file) - 21/Feb/12 3:32 PM

    Merge branch 'ABC-2'
{quote}

h3.Fix

There is none yet.

h3.Workaround
There is none yet.
fields.summary: Bad handling of workflow condition for unreviewed changesets

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
h3. Environment
* JIRA configured applinks with Fisheye
* Repo exists in Fisheye

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# After configured the application link, add the Fisheye Chart gadget in the dashboard 
# Fill in the details including the repository and other information in the gadget
# The type of chart can be Area, Pie or etc. except Line.

h3. Expected Results

The gadget will show the chart accordingly to the type picked in the gadget configuration.

h3. Actual Results
The Fisheye Chart gadget will always show Line graph no matter what chart type you choose.

h3.Workaround
No workaround for now.
fields.summary: Chart Type in FishEye Charts Gadget is not working

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
The Perforce Job Integration configurations do not remain visible in the UI when JIRA is restarted.  The user must manually re-enter the values after a restart for the Perforce integration to operate.

The configurations don't seem to be actually disappearing after the restart as they persist in the database. The issue seems to be in the UI. Rather than recognizing that configurations exist for Perforce Job Integrations, the system acts as if nothing is there.
fields.summary: Perforce Job Integration configurations disappear after restart

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
h4. Steps to repro:

1. Setup JIRA and FeCru and applink the two of them
2. Create an issue, and a review.
3. Put a No open reviews condition in the workflow.
4. Put the issue key in the objectives portion of the review.

h4. Expected
You can transition the issue since this field in Crucible has nothing to do with the Development Panel and since the Crucible data isn't reflected in JIRA it should not have an effect on the workflow.

h4. Actual
The transition is not available.
fields.summary: No open reviews condition incorrectly checks Crucible's "Objectives" field for issue key

This leads me to believe that the error case isn't handled properly for RefreshCachedData. I imagine that any error in this action would produce the same 404 result.

My expectation is that I would receive a Jira-eque error page like I get on the AssociateFishEyeReps action. This page gives an error message in the context of the Administration panel with the message "There was a problem retrieving data from your FishEye instance. Please ensure that you have setup your FishEye connection correctly." rather than a 404.

fields.description:
If there's no source repository of any sort hooked up to a JIRA OnDemand instance, clicking the Source tab shows this:

!source.png!

The Configure button for the Bitbucket section is out of date and goes to https://<hostname>/secure/admin/ConfigureBitbucketOAuth!default.jspa which is a 404. It should be https://<hostname>/secure/admin/ConfigureDvcsOrganizations!default.jspa.
fields.summary: "Configure" link for Bitbucket in Source tab in JIRA OnDemand goes to non-existent URL

Steps to reproduce:
# integrate JIRA to FishEye
# ensure commits has been done to some issues in JIRA

!BrokenChart.png!

fields.description:
The separation of Commits vs Source tag is causing a lot of confusion, as seen at https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/201627/commits-vs-source-tab and https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/196250/jira-6-what-s-the-differences-between-commits-and-source-tabs

Consider merging the two tabs into one.
fields.summary: Consider merging Commits and Source tab

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
h3. Summary
When creating an unproxied applink and changing the Base URL and Display URL to the proxied URL after creation, commits in the other application will take a long time to be updated in JIRA

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Refer to [this documentation|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/KB/How+to+create+an+unproxied+application+link] and create an unproxied application link
# After the link is created using ipaddress in the Application URL, change the Base URL and Display URL to the proxied URL

h3. Expected Results
# All commits in the other application will show up within a few minutes in JIRA

h3. Actual Results
It takes a long time for JIRA to be updated about the commits

h3.Workaround
# No known workaround. Create the applinks using the proxied URL
fields.summary: Commits in FeCru/Stash takes a long time to be updated in JIRA when Display URL and Application URL is different
